awd_titl_txt: Coordinated Supervisory Control System for Smart Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support fundamental research in smart manufacturing processes and systems, promoting the progress of science as well as national prosperity. Recent advancements in sensors, information, communication, and robotics technologies have driven better ways of doing manufacturing. Modern manufacturing systems are equipped with multiple sensors, communication devices, and material handling robots that operate alongside other autonomous machines and human coworkers/supervisors. However, the full potential of these technological advances in improving production efficiency and quality has not been realized. This is because manufacturing systems are inherently stochastic and nonlinear, and there is a lack of theoretical and technical understanding of real-time model-based prediction of manufacturing performance and production control. This research will establish novel data-enabled models for predicting manufacturing system performance under uncertainty and adaptive, robust, and scalable control and coordination algorithms for production control. The new knowledge will provide manufacturers with a rigorous quantitative tool for real-time monitoring and control of the complex manufacturing systems. The results of this research will contribute to both the theory and the practice of smart manufacturing and will be very useful to the entire U.S. manufacturing sector for maximizing productivity and economic benefit. This research incorporates goals with industrial needs, helps broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research, and enhances engineering education. 

This research will fill the knowledge gap via the integrated study of production dynamics and multiple robots material dispatching decisions to address their interactions in real-time, which is significant for manufacturing systems efficiency. The research approach will be a novel combination of dynamic systems modeling of material flow through production processes along with dynamic multirobot task assignment under uncertainty for optimizing production performance metrics. The research team aims to: a) establish a data-enabled mathematical framework to describe real-time manufacturing systems with dynamic production and multirobot operations to enhance the understanding of dynamic manufacturing processes and systems; and b) establish the scientific and technological foundation in adaptive control and decentralized decision making for multirobot system working with machines/humans. The Coordinated Supervisory Control System is based on the holistic view of physical system analysis, advanced data-driven modeling, and adaptive control. The methodology is transformable to other dynamic systems with distributed sensors and data, such as transportation, supply chain, and health care management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Today's manufacturing operations face ever-increasing challenges of variability due to greater customization, new technology insertions, random disruptions, and dramatically fluctuating market demands. The goal of this project is to create adaptive, robust, and scalable control and coordination algorithms for stochastic and nonlinear manufacturing systems that involve multiple material handling robots. These algorithms will enable efficient real-time operations in smart production environments that include autonomous machines and human coworkers or supervisors.

This research aims to lay the scientific and technological foundation for real-time performance prediction and production control in manufacturing. With the support of this NSF grant, a novel framework for a Coordinated Supervisory Control System has been established, incorporating multiple integrated modeling techniques and adaptive control algorithms.

(1)    A data-enabled mathematical modeling approach has been developed to describe the stochastic dynamics of manufacturing processes involving robotic systems. This approach leverages sensor data, such as machine failure events, to provide real-time evaluations of system performance and insights into dynamic properties like opportunity windows and production losses. These insights are crucial for facilitating online process control and optimizing robotic movement decisions.

(2)    A data-driven Graph Neural Network (GNN) model has been developed to address the limitations of traditional model-based approaches. In this model, the manufacturing system is represented as a graph, with machines and robots as nodes and material flows as links. This GNN approach has been validated for its effectiveness in predicting system performance, offering enhanced insights into complex interactions and dependencies within the system.

(3)    A decentralized control scheme has been established, utilizing a multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) approach to address the complexities of manufacturing processes and systems. This control scheme operates on both the data-driven mathematical model and the GNN model to assess the effectiveness of the control strategy and the modeling techniques. The integrated modeling and control approach can enable efficient local control of dynamic process changes, while also providing system-level supervisory control to mitigate bottlenecks through optimized maintenance scheduling and robot allocation. Theoretical analysis and simulation experiments have demonstrated that embedding domain knowledge and system insights into machine learning algorithms significantly enhances both learning efficiency and generalizability. 

(4)    A novel methodology for multi-robot path planning and task assignment under probabilistic uncertainty has been introduced. This optimal solution enables factory floor robots to simultaneously plan collision-free paths and be assigned to tasks, despite uncertainties in task payoffs/costs and the presence of other agents or vehicles in the environment.

(5)    A unique robot Learning from Demonstration (LfD) scheme, based on a single human demonstration, has been developed. A primitive skill library has been created to store essential skills for material handling and assembly tasks in manufacturing. A reinforcement learning (RL) framework is then used to select and combine these skills to perform previously unseen tasks.

(6)    The LfD and reinforcement learning approach has been implemented in industrial testbeds at GM and GE as part of an ARM - Manufacturing USA project. This deployment has validated the effectiveness of the algorithms and successfully elevated the technology readiness level (TRL) from 3 to 6.

This award has broader impacts on education and outreach. The research findings have been integrated into the curricula at the University of Virginia (UVA) and Stony Brook University (SBU), benefiting both undergraduate and graduate programs. At UVA, the project has supported the training of three PhD students, including one female student and one funded through the NSF INTERN program, as well as three undergraduate students through an REU supplement. At SBU, the project has supported two PhD students. The UVA PI has collaborated with the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Program to promote the participation of underrepresented minority students in STEM fields. Meanwhile, the SBU Co-PI has engaged with local high schools on Long Island, NY, involving three K-12 students in research activities that have been featured in science competitions and fairs. The project's findings have been broadly disseminated to both the academic community and the public through conference and journal publications, resulting in 14 journal papers, 11 conference papers, and one completed PhD thesis.
